Sherlock Holmes Visits
Hopkins Campus
Sherlock Holmes was on campus
last Friday.
In the disguise of his friend
Basil Rathbone, Holmes examined
experimental apparatus in the
basement of the Aeronautics building.
He watched two undergraduates
demonstrate a device for analyzing Willi flow on airplane wings
and observed "this would make a
nice present for my (laughter."
When they were through with
the demonstration, he joked, "So
this is what you children do with
your GI Bills."
Upon being asked to come to
the '49ers dance, Holmes gasped,
"Oh, Lord! With two shows staring me in the face. I'd like to,
but I just can't make it."

IFB To Hold
Orphan Day
Inspired by the great success
of the two Christmas parties held
by ATO and DU for underprivileged and crippled children, the
IFB - ha's planned a field day for
around one-hundred local orphans.
Dick Boylan, chairman of the
IFB committee on this new project, states that the tentative date
has been set for April 9. Dick and
his committeemen, Howard Kelly,
George McNeeley, and Malcolm
Mahr, drew up the following plans
for this field day at their meeting
last week. Each fraternity will
take care tid ten of these boys
during the course of the whole
day. The events of the day will
commence with an assembly of
everyone on an athletic field,
where each fraternity will sponsor
a team of orphans in softball and
relay games.
- After the games are over, each
frat will take its team down to
the house for lunch. Following a
hearty meal they will return to
the campus to watch the Hopkins
Loyola lacrosse team.
Fred Lang said this week,
"Hopkins fraternities have in the
much criticism.
past received
Much has been unjustified, but
still the fact remains that there
are many ways in which Hopkins
fraternities can improve the constructive nature of their work.
For this reason the IFB is trying
to seek new fields in which to
encourage the individual fraternities to perform constructive
duties."

Rabbi Lieberman has recently
returned from a visit to Palestine
and Germany where he vivestigated the Displaced Persons situation. His trip was sponsored by
the United Jewish Appeal.
He came to Baltimore 11 years
ago as Assistant Rabbi of the Baltimore Hebrew Congregation after
having graduated from the Hebrew
Union College: He has recently
been made a full rabbi.
During World War II he was a
chaplain in the United States
Army and served in Europe. The
announcement of his talk was
made by Roger Dalsheimer, program chairman of the International Relations Club.

Du Pont research has just made
available to industry what may become one of America's key structural
materials, titanium metal. Midway
in density between aluminum and
iron and with an especially high
melting point,silvery-white titanium
offers an extraordinary combination
of strength, lightness, corrosion resistance and hardness.
Titanium is the ninth most common element. But it has been slow
in coming into its own as a metal because of the difficulty of separating
it in pure form from its ores.

NEWS-LETTER

Homewood, Baltimore, March 18, 1949

After the war, Du Pont scientists
developed a process for the production of ductile titanium metal that
can be scaled up to /meet commercial
demands. The research team that
mastered the complex problem consisted of chemical engineers specializing in design and production, as
well as chemists and a metallurgist.
In September 1948, a pilot plant was
opened with a daily capacity of 100
pounds.Titanium metal is now being
produced in sponge and ingot form.
Samples are available to industrial
and college laboratories with research
projects in related fields. Studies of
methods for forming, machining and
alloying are under way.
Exhaustive studies will be necessary before the many possibilities of
titanium metal can be known. Because of its high ratio of strength to
weight,early uses may be in airplane
power plants and structural parts.
Its hardness and rust-resistance recommend it for railroad transportiation equipment,marine power plants
and propellers, and food packaging
equipment. Its high melting point
suggests use in pistons, and its resistance to electric currents points to
electronics. Titanium wire may be
used for springs and titanium sheet
for such highly stressed parts as
microphone diaphragms.
Your Opportunity In Research
The commercial development of titanium metal is a typical example of
Du Pont research in action. However, the Pigments Department,
which worked out the process, is
but one of the ten Du Pont manufacturing departments. Each conducts continuous research. Each is
operated much like a sepstrate company. Within these "companies"-whose interests range from heavy

Human Rights Immutable
The alleged victory of judicial
positivism in the 19th century was
a victory, not over the. correct
doctrine of natural law, but over
a doctrine "twisted, enlarged and
distorted" by the classical theorists of the 18th century.
Though human rights are immutable and the unNersal possession of them is permanent. exercise of thesetrrights can be limited. Failure to distinguish between the possession and the exercise of human rights is an error
all too widespread among contemporary thinkers, who speak
only of The latter and do not con•

sider the former.
agreephilosophic
Although
ment on the justification of human
rights is far off and difficult of
attainment, the divergent and even
incompatible ideologies current today have issued forth (notably in
the United Nations declaration of
human rights) a common residue
.f "practical truths". This pracal convergence and agreement
onclusioni is possible due to
'elative independence of mor• theoretical thought.
Dignity Of Work
Human rights are not only civil
In nature, but also economic and
social. Among these rights are the
rights to work, to choose work, to
form trade unions, thA autonomy
of workers' groups, the right to a
just wage, to unemployment insui•ance, to social security and to
sici benefits. All of these rights
Involve and are derived from the
dignity of work and the maturity
of the worker.
Two of the most pressing and
dangerous temptations of modern
society are the granting of primacy to economic techniques and
entrusting everything to the power
of the state—which leads in the

Myers Cuts
During the past week, Coach
was confronted
Howdy Myers
with the task of cutting his squad
down into a playing unit of 32
candidates. The future will offer
his molding this unit into the
strongest arrangement possible
with experimental shifts in position being tried where needed.

star, was shifted to the midfield
at the beginning of the practice
sessions. Myers's strategy is beginning to pay dividends for now
Bunting is thoroughly familiar
with his new post and is quickly
shaping up into an adept all-over
the field performer.
Clark Changed Back
Another proposed change of
Coach Myers, that of moving attackman Hedley Clark also to the
midfield, was quickly reversed by
the Jay coach. Now back at
his familiar close attack position, Clark has been outstanding
In his/ work thus far and promises to be a vital cog in his department.
The additional strength offered
in the Jay attack department by
Reds Wolman, Byron Forbush,
Corky Shephard, Mark Stokes, and
Ernie Hansen affords Coach Myers
with the chance of toying with
changes in the close attack. Bill

Du Pont research has just made
available to industry what may become one of America's key structural
materials, titanium metal. Midway
in density between aluminum and
iron and with an especially high
melting point,silvery-white titanium
offers an extraordinary combination
of strength, lightness, corrosion resistance and hardness.
Titanium is the ninth most common element. But it has been slow
in coming into its own as a metal because of the difficulty of separating
it in pure form from its ores.

NEWS-LETTER

Homewood, Baltimore, March 18, 1949

After the war, Du Pont scientists
developed a process for the production of ductile titanium metal that
can be scaled up to /meet commercial
demands. The research team that
mastered the complex problem consisted of chemical engineers specializing in design and production, as
well as chemists and a metallurgist.
In September 1948, a pilot plant was
opened with a daily capacity of 100
pounds.Titanium metal is now being
produced in sponge and ingot form.
Samples are available to industrial
and college laboratories with research
projects in related fields. Studies of
methods for forming, machining and
alloying are under way.
Exhaustive studies will be necessary before the many possibilities of
titanium metal can be known. Because of its high ratio of strength to
weight,early uses may be in airplane
power plants and structural parts.
Its hardness and rust-resistance recommend it for railroad transportiation equipment,marine power plants
and propellers, and food packaging
equipment. Its high melting point
suggests use in pistons, and its resistance to electric currents points to
electronics. Titanium wire may be
used for springs and titanium sheet
for such highly stressed parts as
microphone diaphragms.
Your Opportunity In Research
The commercial development of titanium metal is a typical example of
Du Pont research in action. However, the Pigments Department,
which worked out the process, is
but one of the ten Du Pont manufacturing departments. Each conducts continuous research. Each is
operated much like a sepstrate company. Within these "companies"-whose interests range from heavy

Human Rights Immutable
The alleged victory of judicial
positivism in the 19th century was
a victory, not over the. correct
doctrine of natural law, but over
a doctrine "twisted, enlarged and
distorted" by the classical theorists of the 18th century.
Though human rights are immutable and the unNersal possession of them is permanent. exercise of thesetrrights can be limited. Failure to distinguish between the possession and the exercise of human rights is an error
all too widespread among contemporary thinkers, who speak
only of The latter and do not con•

sider the former.
agreephilosophic
Although
ment on the justification of human
rights is far off and difficult of
attainment, the divergent and even
incompatible ideologies current today have issued forth (notably in
the United Nations declaration of
human rights) a common residue
.f "practical truths". This pracal convergence and agreement
onclusioni is possible due to
'elative independence of mor• theoretical thought.
Dignity Of Work
Human rights are not only civil
In nature, but also economic and
social. Among these rights are the
rights to work, to choose work, to
form trade unions, thA autonomy
of workers' groups, the right to a
just wage, to unemployment insui•ance, to social security and to
sici benefits. All of these rights
Involve and are derived from the
dignity of work and the maturity
of the worker.
Two of the most pressing and
dangerous temptations of modern
society are the granting of primacy to economic techniques and
entrusting everything to the power
of the state—which leads in the

Myers Cuts
During the past week, Coach
was confronted
Howdy Myers
with the task of cutting his squad
down into a playing unit of 32
candidates. The future will offer
his molding this unit into the
strongest arrangement possible
with experimental shifts in position being tried where needed.
Lloyd Bunting, '48 defensive
star, was shifted to the midfield
at the beginning of the practice
sessions. Myers's strategy is beginning to pay dividends for now
Bunting is thoroughly familiar
with his new post and is quickly
shaping up into an adept all-over
the field performer.
Clark Changed Back
Another proposed change of
Coach Myers, that of moving attackman Hedley Clark also to the
midfield, was quickly reversed by
the Jay coach. Now back at
his familiar close attack position, Clark has been outstanding
In his/ work thus far and promises to be a vital cog in his department.
The additional strength offered
in the Jay attack department by
Reds Wolman, Byron Forbush,
Corky Shephard, Mark Stokes, and
Ernie Hansen affords Coach Myers
with the chance of toying with
changes in the close attack. Bill
